Package Reference#

Inferly-client has two cornerstone objects: Datasets and Models. To both of them we can attach various diagnostics such as plots or metrics.

Data#

class inferlyclient.data.Dataset(df, input_names, output_names)[source]#

Main class for handling datasets.

Parameters:

  • df (pandas dataframe) – Dataframe containing the data.

  • input_names (list of strings) – Name of the columns associated with input variables.

  • output_names (list of strings) – Name of the columns associated with output variables.

input_names#

value passed at construction.

Type:

list of strings

output_names#

value passed at construction.

Type:

list of strings

data#

n x input_dim dataframe

Type:

pandas DataFrame

split(sizes, labels, seed=None)[source]#

Split a dataset, typically into a training and test set.

The method also adds a column to the dataset’s dataframe to indicate whether a point is in the training or test set.

Parameters:

  • sizes (list of integers) – number of points to keep for each split.

  • labels (list) – labels associated with each split.

  • seed (int) – Seed for the random number generator.

Returns:

Training set with n_train entries. test_set (Dataset): Test set with remaining entries.

Return type:

train_set (Dataset)

inferlyclient.data.cartesian_product(X1, X2)[source]#

Generates the cartesian product of two DoEs.

Example The following code generates a cartesian product of two dataframes with 11 and 5 points respectively. The resulting output is a dataframe with 55 points.

import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import inferlyclient as infly

X1 = pd.DataFrame(np.linspace(0, 1, 11), columns=['x1'])
X2 = pd.DataFrame(np.linspace(0, 1, 5), columns=['x2'])
X = infly.doe.cartesian_product(X1, X2)

print(X)
Parameters:

  • X1 (pd.DataFrame) – first Doe, say with $n_1$ rows and $dim_1$ columns.

  • X2 (pd.DataFrame) – second Doe, say with $n_2$ rows and $dim_2$ columns.

Return type:

DataFrame

Returns:

dataframe with $n_1 times n_2$ rows and $d_1 + d_2$ columns.

inferlyclient.data.doe_kmeans(n, dim, input_names=None)[source]#

Generates a Design of Experiment (DoE) where points are uniformely distributed in the unit cube.

The DoE is obtained by running a k-means algorithm with $n$ classes on a large number of uniformly sampled points. This procedure ensures that the resulting DoE has a lower discrepency than $n$ uniformly sampled points.

Parameters:

  • n (int) – number of points in the DoE.

  • dim (int) – dimension of the space.

  • input_names (Optional, list of strings) – variable name for each dimension.

Return type:

DataFrame

Returns:

pandas DataFrame of shape n x dim.

inferlyclient.data.gridplot(df, var_names_haxis, var_names_vaxis, **kwargs)[source]#

Grid plot with variables from a dataframe.

This is similar to pairsplot but allows to specify different variables for the horizontal and vertical axis.

Parameters:

  • df (pandas.Dataframe) – dataframe.

  • var_names_haxis (list of str) – names of variables to be ploted on the horizontal axis.

  • var_names_vaxis (list of str) – names of variables to be ploted on the vertical axis.

  • **kwargs – additional arguments passed to plotly.express.scatter.

Return type:

Figure

Returns:

plotly figure

inferlyclient.data.pairsplot(df, var_names, **kwargs)[source]#

Grid plot with variables from a dataframe.

Parameters:

  • df (panda.Dataframe) – dataframe.

  • var_names (list of str) – names of variables to be ploted on the horizontal axis.

  • **kwargs – additional arguments passed to plotly.express.scatter_matrix.

Return type:

Figure

Returns:

plotly figure

inferlyclient.data.standardise_rescaling(data)[source]#

Computes the linear bijector that maps the data to zero mean unit variance.

Parameters:

data (pandas DataFrame) – dataframe used to infer the first two moments.

Returns:

bijector that maps the data to the standard normal.

Return type:

tfp.bijectors.Bijector

inferlyclient.data.unit_cube_rescaling(data)[source]#

Computes the linear bijector that maps the data to the unit cube.

Parameters:

data (pandas DataFrame) – dataframe used to infer the bounds.

Returns:

bijector that maps the data to the unit cube.

Return type:

tfp.bijectors.Bijector

Models#

class inferlyclient.models.GPmodel(gpflow, input_transform=<tfp.bijectors.Identity 'identity' batch_shape=[] forward_min_event_ndims=0 inverse_min_event_ndims=0 dtype_x=? dtype_y=?>, output_transform=<tfp.bijectors.Identity 'identity' batch_shape=[] forward_min_event_ndims=0 inverse_min_event_ndims=0 dtype_x=? dtype_y=?>)[source]#

Wrapper around GPflow models to include input and output transforms.

Parameters:

  • gpflow (GPModel) – a gpflow model, where the data has already been transformed

  • input_transform (Bijector) – a tensorflow probability bijector

  • output_transform (Bijector) – a tensorflow probability bijector

predict_y()[source]#
predict_quantiles()[source]#
predict_log_density()[source]#
predict_log_density(data)[source]#

Wrapper around gpflow.models.predict_density that applies the input and output transforms.

Parameters:

data (Dataset) –

Return type:

Tensor

predict_quantiles(Xnew, levels)[source]#

Wrapper around gpflow.models.predict_y that applies the input and output transforms.

Parameters:

  • Xnew (tf.Tensor, shape n * input_dim) – input_dim tensor of inputs.

  • levels (tf.Tensor, shape m) – tensor of quantile levels, expressed in [0, 1].

Returns:

m x n x output_dim tensor of quantiles.

Return type:

quantiles (tf.Tensor)

predict_y(Xnew)[source]#

Wrapper around gpflow.models.predict_y that applies the input and output transforms.

Parameters:

Xnew (tf.Tensor) – n x input_dim tensor of inputs

Returns:

n x output_dim tensor of means var (tf.Tensor): n x output_dim tensor of variances

Return type:

mean (tf.Tensor)

inferlyclient.models.nlpd(model, test_data)[source]#

Negative log predictive density (i.e. minus the average of the log likelihood on test set).

Parameters:

  • model (GPmodel) – A GPmodel object.

  • test_data (inferlycore Dataset) – test data.

Returns:

The negative log predictive density.

Return type:

float

inferlyclient.models.plot_actual_vs_predicted(model, data)[source]#

Plot actual vs predicted values.

Parameters:

  • model (GPmodel) – A GPmodel object.

  • data (inferlycore Dataset) – Dataset to compare model train/predictions.

Return type:

Figure

inferlyclient.models.plot_lengthscales(kernel, inputs, **kwargs)[source]#

Spider chart to inspect the lengthscales.

Parameters:

  • kernel (gpflow kernel) – ARD kernel from a GPflow model.

  • inputs (list of strings) – the name of the variables associated with each input dimension.

  • **kwargs – keyword arguments passed to plotly.express.line_polar.

inferlyclient.models.plot_slices(model, input_names, output_names, reference_point, xlim)[source]#

Plot slices of the posterior distribution at a reference point.

Parameters:

  • model (GPmodel) – A GPmodel object.

  • input_names (list of strings) – the name of the variables associated with each input dimension.

  • output_names (list of strings) – the name of the variables associated with each output dimension.

  • reference_point (tf.Tensor) – A reference point in the input space with shape [1, dim]. All slices will cut through this point.

  • xlim (tf.Tensor) – A tensor of shape [2, dim] with the lower and upper limits of the x-axis.

inferlyclient.models.q2(model, test_data)[source]#

Percentage of explained variance.

Q2 is equal to 1 if the model predicts perfectly, and 0 if the model predicts as well as the mean value of the test set.

Parameters:

  • model (GPmodel) – A GPmodel object.

  • test_data (inferlycore Dataset) – test data.

Returns:

The q2 metrics for each output.

Return type:

float

inferlyclient.models.rmse(model, test_data)[source]#

Root mean squared error.

Parameters:

  • model (GPmodel) – A GPmodel object.

  • test_data (tuple[tf.Tensor, tf.Tensor]) – A tuple of tensors (Xtest, Ytest) with the test data.

Returns:

The root mean squared error.

Return type:

float
